subject: Re: [junit] Literate asserts
msgSnippet: ... Agreed... and this is why I really like the human string approach. I am quite sure a human message will be almost always better than a pregenerated one.
messageBody:
On 12/1/06, Jeff Langr <jeff@...> wrote:
>
> Quoting Alexandru Popescu <the.mindstorm.mailinglist@...>:
> >> How about:
> >>
> >> assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))
> >>
> >> and I would have thought
> >>
> >> assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().lessThan(10))
> >>
> >> should be possible as well.
> >>
> >
> > ... but are you sure it is more readable than:
> >
> > assertTrue( 2 < n && n < 10, "n should be inside the (2, 10) interval");
>
> The main benefit of literate programming that I gather from reading
> earlier messages is that it makes the error messages easier to read.
> Given this example:
> assert(that(n).greaterThan(2).and().that(n).lessThan(10))
> it seems to me to be at the expense of the readability of the tests
> (in some cases), and also likely at the expense of amount of effort
> required to code the tests. But maybe that's a good tradeoff.
>

Agreed... and this is why I really like the human string approach. I
am quite sure a human message will be almost always better than a
pregenerated one. And I left aside the fact that reading the
assert(that()...................) is really hurting my eyes :-).

> [trimmed /]
> Given all the choices, I think the Java language makes the literate
> programming one the least appealing to me. It is what it is.
>

Not sure if less appealing, but we still have limitted possibilites.

./alex
